awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Testing Important Judgment/Decision Making Phenomena in the High-Incentive Context of Covid-19: The Understanding of Physicians and Laypersons
awd_abstract_narration:
The coronavirus pandemic provides a rare opportunity to study public risk perceptions and risk-related behaviors in the midst of a World Health Organization Public Health Emergency of International Concern that could threaten the quality of life of a wide spectrum of Americans. Few emergencies within the United States have affected so many people. The situation is a rich opportunity because it is occurring in real-time and is highly dynamic, involving many players in our country and around the world. As a result, it allows the research team a chance to compare this health threat with other perceived disasters such as immigration, terrorism, and possible future public health emergencies. The public’s perceptions and risk-related behaviors seem likely to change over time in response to media coverage as well as actions from our own and foreign governments.
 
In one longitudinal study, the research team invites participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk to complete one survey each month for 5 months. The researchers query their risk perceptions and affective responses toward the coronavirus, frequency of discussions about the coronavirus with others, behavioral intentions towards hypothetical experimental vaccines and treatments, and support for possible policy solutions such as quarantine. The research also ascertains their intended travel plans and media exposure to the pandemic including how much they trust those sources. The team models the emotional, risk-perception, and behavioral responses of participants toward the coronavirus by using a latent variable growth curve model that examines the trajectories of variables over time. To establish causal links, the scholars also conduct a second related experiment that manipulates affect through narratives and examines its effects on risk perceptions, medical decisions, and policy decisions. Participants are assigned to a more negative or less negative condition, and mediation analysis is used to evaluate the manipulation’s effects. In these studies, theoretical links are made between risk perceptions, social amplification of risk, the affect heuristic and other functions of affect, and numeracy. There is a dynamic test of the three functions of affect by correlating current feelings over time with risk judgments, intended prevention and treatment behaviors, and support for policy options. Theoretical research on affect has not been tested in the setting of a world health emergency. This research results in deep mechanistic understanding of how emotions and media exposure influence vaccine and treatment choices as well as support for policies. Finally, the second study establishes causal links between affect and support for prevention, treatment, and policy strategies. The research tests the dynamic and causal power of the functions of affect and motivated reasoning in order to lay the groundwork for interventions for emotional responses to the coronavirus and future epidemics. The research also has important implications, including for communication methods, for other affect-rich decisions faced by the public and policy makers.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to test performance on a number of traditional judgment-decision making (JDM) tasks. Such tasks have been used either in story problems or in low-stakes scenarios. With Covid there is an opportunity to test performance in a high-stakes situation, because the scenarios presented to all participants will be incorporated into a Covid context. Another goal is to test not only laypersons but also physicians. On some traditional judgment-decision making (JDM) tasks physicians have exhibited weak performance. Will their performance improve when tested in a high-stakes Covid situation? 

We found that physicians and laypeople performed similarly. The major key outcome was that the COVID context sometimes had a salutary influence and sometimes a detrimental influence. On easy tasks where the correct answer is dominant or apparent, higher motivation--fear of Covid in our studies--resulted in improved performance. When the task is more difficult because the correct choice is not apparent and an incorrect choice is appealing, higher motivation detracts from performance.

For example, consider a choice between two drugs. Drug A protects 1 out of every 10 people who take it from getting COVID-19. Drug B protects 9 out of 100 every people who take it from getting COVID-19.

The traditional, non-COVID version of this problem is as follows: Imagine two bowls of jellybeans. Bowl A has 10 jellybeans; Bowl B has 100 jellybeans. If you pick a colored bean out of a bowl, you win $5. You can choose between Bowl A that has 1 colored bean out of 10 or Bowl B that has 9 colored beans out of 100.

In both cases, choosing the 1 out of 10 option is better than 9 out of 100 (10% vs. 9% of a positive outcome, respectively). People who choose option B are committing denominator neglect. We found that people (both doctors and laypeople) performed better in the COVID-19 drug problem than the jellybean problem. Furthermore, the difference between the two problems was more pronounced for people who perceived COVID-19 as riskier.

In contrast, a much more difficult problem is the classic Wason four card problem: Here are four cards. On one side of each card we’ve placed a letter. On the other side of each card we’ve placed a number. Here are the cards you can see: E K 7 4

Which card(s) MUST be turned over to test this statement: “If there is a vowel on one side of the card, there will be an even number on the other side of the card.”?

A COVID version was also created: Here are four medical records. On one side of each record we've indicated whether the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19. On the other side of each record we've indicated whether the person has or does not have COVID-19. Here are the records you can see: Vaccinated. Not vaccinated. Has COVID-19. Does not have COVID-19.

Which medical record(s) MUST be turned over to test this statement "Everyone who has been vaccinated does not have COVID-19"?

The correct answer in this case is to select both E (to check if there’s an even number) and 7 (to be sure there isn’t a vowel). Similarly, in the COVID version, you must check “Vaccinated” to be sure that they don’t have COVID-19 and you must also check “Has COVID-19” to be sure that they weren’t vaccinated. People did worse on this task than other tasks, but particularly in the COVID-19 context. In this case, we concluded that the more motivating COVID-19 context hurt performance.

We tried approximately 20 times to manipulate COVID-19 emotion/fear, but fear of COVID-19 declined during the course of our investigation, and we were unable to achieve a sufficiently strong fear manipulation of either COVID-19 or other diseases. Because we could not experimentally manipulate COVID-19 fear, we cannot conclude that COVID-19 fear caused differential performance on the easy vs. difficult tasks.
